Are you interested in working as a travel nurse? Have you ever heard of working as a per diem nurse?

What exactly is the difference between the two? We explore what it means to be a travel nurse and what it means to be a per diem nurse – and the pros and cons of both types of nursing careers.

What is Per Diem Nursing?

To understand what it means to work as a per diem nurse you basically just need to know that “per diem” means “by the day”. While the terms and conditions vary according to the hospital or nursing agency you work for, a per diem nurse is similar to a nurse working on call in the sense that they may be called and offered a shift simply hours before it starts.

Per diem nursing also differs from being an on-call nurse because they may have been assigned a shift, or a couple of weeks of shifts, to cover a hospital’s upcoming openings due to vacation or time off in advance. A per diem nurse might also work longer or shorter hours, by being willing to come in and pick up half a shift, a full shift, a shift and a half, or even a double.

Similar to how travel nurses are brought in to cover periods of increased demands such as flu season, holidays, or summer when nurses often take vacations, a per diem nurse might be hired for this type of coverage.

If you love flexibility and being able to decide when and where you want to work, you might enjoy working as a per diem nurse. Just think, your nursing agency calls you and you can decide whether or not to accept a shift. You also might be offered many holiday shifts, in which you can earn that sweet time and a half, double time, or even more in certain instances.

What are the Advantages of Per Diem Nursing?

  • Nurses choose when and where they want to work.
  • Per diem nurses can decline a shift if they don’t feel like working.
  • Per diem nurses work on a temporary basis through hospitals or agencies.
  • Nurses working per diem can earn higher salaries than the regular staff nurses they work next to.
  • Per diem nursing allows you to be more available for your family and children.
  • When working as a per diem nurse, you are not tied or obligated to a specific work schedule.
  • Per diem nurses are not required to work a holiday or a weekend – ever.

What are the Disadvantages of Working as a Per Diem Nurse?

  • Per diem nurses do not receive job benefits.
  • Sometimes there is less of a need for per diem nurses.
  • Per diem nurses may have to go a week or two without work.
  • Financial strain can result if there is no other source of benefits or income for the nurse.
  • There is relatively low job security,
  • Assignments may be canceled, even last minute.

What is Travel Nursing?

Travel nursing assignments typically range from 13 to 25 weeks and include a large number of specialties. Much like per diem nurses, travel nurses are hired for just a limited time at a specific location. A travel nurse may go anywhere and everywhere around the country to help fill in the gaps for patients who need them most in hospitals with extended staffing needs.

Travel nurses are able to choose between a plethora of travel nursing assignments in various locations throughout the United States for different lengths of time. Typically nurses who travel love this freedom which allows them to choose where and when they want to work. Nurses who love the ability to take off extra time when needed and not be stuck in the same old routine day after day might love the freedom travel nursing jobs provide.

Have you ever been stuck working for a company that didn’t quite meet your expectations in terms of management? If you were working as a travel nurse, you’d have the ability to shop around and try out different travel nursing agencies and even choose your own travel nurse recruiter for your next assignment.

What are the Advantages of Travel Nursing?

  • Travel nursing benefits are generous and include things such as:
    • Paid housing and expenses
    • Tax-free benefits
    • Full medical, dental, and vision insurance benefits
    • Sign-on, referral, and completion bonuses
    • Licensure reimbursement
  • Travel nurses can decide where they want to live and work.
  • Essentially, working as a travel nurse can feel like being on vacation, all the time.
  • Travel nurses are able to take substantial time off in between assignments.
  • For those looking to beat the weather for a season, they can take a travel nursing assignment in a location with a different climate.
  • Nurses who travel can decide to change locations as often as the contracts allow, or pick up new contracts in the same area or state.
  • Travel nurses have numerous opportunities for personal and professional growth by working and living in new locations.
  • If you’re considering moving to a certain location, working there first as a travel nurse can give you a better idea of how you like it.
  • Working as a travel nurse brings in higher pay than working as a staff nurse, which allows provides for a comfortable lifestyle.
  • Paid housing benefits allow travel nurses to bypass the inflated costs of living in the United States.
  • Unlike per diem nurses, travel nurses enjoy the security of guaranteed hours, which means they are not able to be canceled, or cancellation policies, which allow them to get paid in the rare event they were called off the shift.
  • Travel nurses are often given the opportunity to extend their contract if there is still a need at the facility.

What are the Disadvantages of Travel Nursing?

  • Travel nurses do not have as much flexibility in their schedule as do per diem nurses.
  • Usually, travel nurses are required to work the same shifts in terms of every other weekend and holidays, as are staff nurses.
  • If the travel nurse is not satisfied with their nursing staffing agency or management at a hospital, they are still required to complete the duration of the contract.

Do You Want to Advance Your Nursing Career and Work as a Travel or Per Diem Nurse?

Are you ready to jump into the fast-paced and exciting world of travel and per diem nursing? If so, we can’t wait to speak to you! At Elite Specialty Staffing, we place professionals on travel nursing assignments throughout the United States and hire per diem nurses to work in the states of Utah, Idaho, and Nevada.

No matter which type of nursing assignments appeal to you, we’re here to explore options! Take a look at our available jobs today.

posts.title: How to Survive the First Day at a Travel Nursing Job
posts.markdown:
[et_pb_section admin_label=”section”] [et_pb_row admin_label=”row”] [et_pb_column type=”4_4″][et_pb_text admin_label=”Text”]You might be feeling a little nervous about your first day on the job at a new travel nursing assignment. Worried. Apprehensive. Excited, even. However you feel, keep in mind that you don’t have to step onto the floor unprepared! Whether you are a first-time travel nurse or a seasoned nurse who travels, here are some travel nursing tips to help you calm those first day jitters and step into your new position feeling confident and ready to rock and roll!  


## 1. Know Where to Go and What to Do on Arrival

 This first tip is huge. Whether you are starting an assignment in a state far away from home or just a couple of hours away, you need to know where to go. I’m not just talking about how to get to the facility. It’s also important that you know what to do once you arrive! Try taking a dry run the day before. With factors involved, such as traffic, construction, and other commute timing issues, even with Google Maps or GPS en route – you may find the transit takes more or less time than anticipated. Take a dry run the day before your assignment. Leave at the time you think you’ll need to leave on day one so that you can figure out the route. Once you arrive at the facility, it’s important that you figure out where to park. Sometimes just finding the right spot in the parking garage and walking into the hospital can consume a significant amount of your allotted time for preparation, especially when working at a large hospital. Your recruiter should have you well-equipped with instructions for your first day. These will include where to go once you arrive, where to sign in, what you’re supposed to wear, and a basic rundown of what to expect when you get there. During your test run, be sure to figure out how much time it takes to get to the unit you’ll be working on or signing in at. Be sure that you also get the phone number to the hospital and have it saved in your phone, just in case you need it later.   
## 2. Get a Solid Night’s Rest

 Just like a child who can’t sleep on Christmas Eve, busy anticipating what the next day will hold, you may find it hard to close your eyes and get sound rest the night before the first day of a travel nursing assignment (except that you know there are no presents in store besides maybe a hospital pen and a name badge). Even though your body will likely be worked up and your mind racing with thoughts about the next day, it’s imperative that you follow a good routine and lay down early to be sure that you get adequate rest for your first day. Avoid sugar and caffeine the night before a travel assignment. If there is anything you normally do to help you relax, such as drinking a glass of wine or taking a long bubble bath – do so the night before your first day to ensure you drift off to sleep.   
## 3. Bring Everything You Need to Work on Day One

 Even if your recruiter has assured you that the first day is just an orientation to the facility and you won’t be required to work, come prepared to work anyways. Anything can happen. Bring your scrubs, proper footwear, name badge, your favorite pen, stethoscope, all those tools you need to perform your job duties. Additionally, bring copies of all your paperwork, licenses, certifications, and pocket cards, even if your recruiter has already sent these documents in. Nothing is more stressful than arriving and being turned down to work right away by human resources because you are missing a piece of documentation. Ideally, you should have these items both printed off and saved as digital copies on a USB drive. You never know how long orientation might last so pack a healthy snack and a bottle of water. Also, be sure to bring some cash too, because every facility does not take credit cards for lunch.   
## 4. Show Up Early to Your First Day of a Travel Nursing Assignment

 First impressions are everything. Consider how long the “dry run” took you to arrive at the facility, and adjust your departure time accordingly. Ideally, you should arrive about 15 minutes early. Do your best to continue this routine throughout the duration of your travel nursing assignment. This consistency will also look great on your resume for future jobs and your travel nursing recruiter can stress this as one of your merits to potential employers in the future.   
## 5. Get Oriented to the Routine Fast with the Right Questions

 As a travel nurse, your hospital or facility orientation is going to be fast-paced. You’re going to learn the most when you are actually on the job. It’s important that you know which questions to ask. Write down a list of questions that you want to know, such as codes to access the laundry or medication rooms, specific unit policies regarding insulin administration, who is able to start IVs on the unit, what can be delegated to unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP), etc.   
## 6. Bring a Positive Attitude and a Team Spirit

 Smile big on your first day. Even if you are nervous, this smile will help you look *and* feel more confident. Be ready to jump in and help out your fellow team members on the floor. Sometimes you might be given a lesser assignment on your first day so that you can quickly orient to the unit and workflow. If this is the case and you find yourself with some extra time, be sure to jump in and assist other team members that need an extra hand.   
## 7. Introduce Yourself and Take Names

 Even if you know that you won’t remember their names in the next hour – at least try and make the effort. Introduce yourself to your new co-workers with a confident smile and a firm handshake. Make a special effort to remember the names of those you will be working with on a consistent basis. Remember, at most facilities, you also work with UAP, secretaries, or LPNs, that should be given the same respect. Be sure not to just make an effort to get to know your fellow nurses, but the others you will be working directly with as these staff members often become the ones you will interact with the most.   
## Discover Your Next Travel Nursing Job Today

 Are you a first-time travel nurse looking to secure your first assignment? Are you a seasoned travel RN browsing contract options for your next adventure? Either way, we have jobs ready for you! Take a look at our [job board](/jobs/) to see what’s waiting for you at Elite Staffing Agency, your premier nurse staffing company.  [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column] [/et_pb_row] [/et_pb_section]

With factors involved, such as traffic, construction, and other commute timing issues, even with Google Maps or GPS en route – you may find the transit takes more or less time than anticipated. Take a dry run the day before your assignment. Leave at the time you think you’ll need to leave on day one so that you can figure out the route. Once you arrive at the facility, it’s important that you figure out where to park. Sometimes just finding the right spot in the parking garage and walking into the hospital can consume a significant amount of your allotted time for preparation, especially when working at a large hospital. Your recruiter should have you well-equipped with instructions for your first day. These will include where to go once you arrive, where to sign in, what you’re supposed to wear, and a basic rundown of what to expect when you get there. During your test run, be sure to figure out how much time it takes to get to the unit you’ll be working on or signing in at. Be sure that you also get the phone number to the hospital and have it saved in your phone, just in case you need it later.  

2. Get a Solid Night’s Rest

Just like a child who can’t sleep on Christmas Eve, busy anticipating what the next day will hold, you may find it hard to close your eyes and get sound rest the night before the first day of a travel nursing assignment (except that you know there are no presents in store besides maybe a hospital pen and a name badge). Even though your body will likely be worked up and your mind racing with thoughts about the next day, it’s imperative that you follow a good routine and lay down early to be sure that you get adequate rest for your first day. Avoid sugar and caffeine the night before a travel assignment. If there is anything you normally do to help you relax, such as drinking a glass of wine or taking a long bubble bath – do so the night before your first day to ensure you drift off to sleep.  

3. Bring Everything You Need to Work on Day One

Even if your recruiter has assured you that the first day is just an orientation to the facility and you won’t be required to work, come prepared to work anyways. Anything can happen. Bring your scrubs, proper footwear, name badge, your favorite pen, stethoscope, all those tools you need to perform your job duties. Additionally, bring copies of all your paperwork, licenses, certifications, and pocket cards, even if your recruiter has already sent these documents in. Nothing is more stressful than arriving and being turned down to work right away by human resources because you are missing a piece of documentation. Ideally, you should have these items both printed off and saved as digital copies on a USB drive. You never know how long orientation might last so pack a healthy snack and a bottle of water. Also, be sure to bring some cash too, because every facility does not take credit cards for lunch.  

4. Show Up Early to Your First Day of a Travel Nursing Assignment

First impressions are everything. Consider how long the “dry run” took you to arrive at the facility, and adjust your departure time accordingly. Ideally, you should arrive about 15 minutes early. Do your best to continue this routine throughout the duration of your travel nursing assignment. This consistency will also look great on your resume for future jobs and your travel nursing recruiter can stress this as one of your merits to potential employers in the future.  

5. Get Oriented to the Routine Fast with the Right Questions

As a travel nurse, your hospital or facility orientation is going to be fast-paced. You’re going to learn the most when you are actually on the job. It’s important that you know which questions to ask. Write down a list of questions that you want to know, such as codes to access the laundry or medication rooms, specific unit policies regarding insulin administration, who is able to start IVs on the unit, what can be delegated to unlicensed assistive personnel (UAP), etc.  

6. Bring a Positive Attitude and a Team Spirit

Smile big on your first day. Even if you are nervous, this smile will help you look and feel more confident. Be ready to jump in and help out your fellow team members on the floor. Sometimes you might be given a lesser assignment on your first day so that you can quickly orient to the unit and workflow. If this is the case and you find yourself with some extra time, be sure to jump in and assist other team members that need an extra hand.  

7. Introduce Yourself and Take Names

Even if you know that you won’t remember their names in the next hour – at least try and make the effort. Introduce yourself to your new co-workers with a confident smile and a firm handshake. Make a special effort to remember the names of those you will be working with on a consistent basis. Remember, at most facilities, you also work with UAP, secretaries, or LPNs, that should be given the same respect. Be sure not to just make an effort to get to know your fellow nurses, but the others you will be working directly with as these staff members often become the ones you will interact with the most.  

Discover Your Next Travel Nursing Job Today

Are you a first-time travel nurse looking to secure your first assignment? Are you a seasoned travel RN browsing contract options for your next adventure? Either way, we have jobs ready for you! Take a look at our job board to see what’s waiting for you at Elite Staffing Agency, your premier nurse staffing company.  [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column] [/et_pb_row] [/et_pb_section]

posts.title: What are the top 10 Highest Paying Travel Nursing Jobs?
posts.markdown:
Do you want to explore the highest paying travel nursing jobs in the United States? You’ve come to the right place.

Travel nursing benefits are numerous and the generous travel nursing salary is only just one of those! However, because the income a travel nurse makes during an assignment is the biggest deciding factor on whether or not to take a job, it’s a huge one! We explore the top 10 highest paying travel nursing jobs. Here we go.


## 1. Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist (CRNA)

### Annual Salary: $105,000 to $133,000

When it comes to travel nursing jobs, CRNAs top the list for the highest earning potential! In order for a registered nurse to become a CRNA, they must obtain a Master’s Degree. Certified registered nurse anesthetists must be great team players to interact with the surgical team and they must hold the ultimate level of skill and concentration to keep patients safe during surgical procedures.

In addition to mixing and administering the anesthesia, they are often the professional in charge of prepping a patient for a surgical procedure. Settings in which CRNAs often work include hospitals, dental surgical offices, and outpatient surgery centers.


## 2. Certified Nurse Midwife (CNM)

### Annual Salary: $75,000 to $105,000

Predicted to grow faster than most other professions, midwives are in very high demand. If you’re a nurse that loves to work in the OB/GYN field, you may want to consider working as a traveling certified nurse midwife.

Midwives are best known for providing prenatal care and assisting during labor and delivery, but they actually provide the full spectrum of women’s health services. According to [Midwife.org](http://www.midwife.org/), “53.3% of CNMs identify reproductive care and 33.1% identify primary care as main responsibilities in their full-time positions.”

Responsibilities of midwives include:

- Prescribing medications
- Providing prenatal, labor, and birth care
- Educating and counseling


## 3. General Nurse Practitioner (NP)

### Annual Salary: $75,000 to $97,000

Becoming a nurse practitioner is a great choice for any registered nurse who wants to advance their nursing career and get into a comfortable position with a great salary and even greater flexibility. It’s in high demand and jobs are literally everywhere from local doctors’ offices to hospitals.

If you are the type of nurse that enjoys working directly with patients, you might enjoy a career as a nurse practitioner whose responsibilities include:

- Recommending treatment options and plans
- Assessing patient medical history
- Providing medical education on preventative healthcare practices
- Listening to patients and understanding and considering their symptoms


## 4. Gerontological Nurse Practitioner

### Annual Salary: $75,000 to $95,000 per year

Do you love working with the elderly? If so, you might want to explore a career as a traveling gerontological nurse practitioner. Because there is a growing number of geriatric patients and they are more prone to injury and disease than the general population, the demand for this type of NP is quite high and responsibilities include:

- Mental health and psychiatric care
- Assistance with meeting daily living and hygiene needs
- Screening patients and providing preventative care
- Treating patients for aches and pains


## 5. Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner

### Annual Salary: $70,000 to $90,000

There is a growing demand for nurse practitioners who work in a psychiatric setting. Many jobs are available throughout the nation for mental health nurse practitioner, including temporary and travel nursing assignments with top pay. You might expect to work in a variety of settings, including:

- Correctional facilities
- Mental health centers
- Hospitals


## 6. Nurse Researcher

### Annual Salary: $75,000 to $95,000

Nurse researchers are those work in hospitals, clinics, and research laboratories and help conduct research studies. These nurses create and design studies to test a hypothesis and make improvements in patient care delivery based on the findings.


## 7. Pain Management Nurse

### Annual Salary: $85,000 to $90

Pain management nurses are employed at hospitals and healthcare facilities throughout the nation to help patients control their pain. They work with patients who suffer from chronic pain and acute pain. In addition to providing relief with pain medications, they also help with alternative pain management techniques and teach patients about how to effectively manage their pain and avoid addiction and dependency. Nurses who work in pain management help providers determine the cause of pain and develop treatment plans.


## 8. Informatics Nurse

### Annual Salary: $78,000 to $83,000

Nurses who work in informatics are responsible for managing the IT side of healthcare as it applies to the nursing profession to help improve care. They will work alongside the hospital or healthcare facility’s IT team to develop and implement technological solutions and applications that are well-received by the nurses and improve care delivery. They often serve as a middle man between the clinical staff and the technical staff at a facility.


## 9. Neonatal Nurse

### Annual Salary: $65,000 to $75,000

If you have a passion for taking care of babies and experience in this area, you may want to consider a position as a neonatal nurse. This position allows for advancement which commands higher pay. While a staff RN can perform this job, if you obtain certification as a neonatal nurse practitioner (NNP) or neonatal clinical nurse specialist (CNS) – you unlock the real potential for high pay in this role.


## 9. Neonatal Nurse

### Annual Salary: $65,000 to $75,000

If you have a passion for taking care of babies and experience in this area, you may want to consider a position as a neonatal nurse. This position allows for advancement which commands higher pay. While a staff RN can perform this job, if you obtain certification as a neonatal nurse practitioner (NNP) or neonatal clinical nurse specialist (CNS) – you unlock the real potential for high pay in this role.


## Ready to Search the Highest-Paying Travel Nursing Jobs?

### Find a travel assignment in your specialty today.

[Fill out an online application](https://elitespecialtystaffing.com/apply/) or give us a call at 208-378-1338 to find out what kind of travel nursing jobs our specialty staffing agency has for you.

posts.title: Is New Jersey Going to Join the Nurse Licensure Compact?
posts.markdown:
Nursing shortages are a grave threat to public health and affect nearly every state across the nation. New Jersey is certainly no exception to this rule. Experts predict that by the year 2030, the workforce in NJ is going to be lacking about 11,400 nurses in order to meet the demand for medical services in the state.

Impeding worsening of this nursing shortage has caused the two-decade-old debate over whether New Jersey will join the [enhanced Nurse Licensure Compact](https://www.ncsbn.org/11945.htm) (eNLC) to re-emerge. Just last month, a big step was taken in the direction of adding New Jersey to the agreement that will allow nurses licensed in the state to freely practice in the 29 other states already in the agreement – and it will also open the doors for those same nurses in compact states to practice in New Jersey.


## New Legislation that Adds the Garden State to the eNLC has been Introduced

On February 21, 2019, the New Jersey State Senate approved in a unanimous vote a piece of legislation that will authorize the state to participate in the multi-state Nurse Licensure Compact which is known as the eNLC. This is a national program that provides mobility and freedom for nurse professionals to work in multiple states in order to combat the plague of nursing shortages affecting the US. Other technology is also propped up by the nursing license compact through the support of telemedicine and other care delivery that crosses state borders.


## How Does the Enhanced Nurse Licensure Compact Work?

While there is still a final vote needed in the Assembly, the eNLC model that has been outlined in the NJ legislation would require nurses to meet the licensing qualifications set forth by the state in which they reside, whether that be NJ or another member state.

When any travel nurse in the compact is working and providing care, they must still meet all of the regulations set forth by the state in which they are practicing. Furthermore, the multi-state compact also has a shared database in which all states must enter any nursing violations into the system.


## What are the Concerns Over NJ Entering the eNLC?

While many are in full support of the Garden State becoming the next to join the eNLC, there are some nursing groups who remain opposed to the change. What are their reasons?

New Jersey is a bit heavy when it comes to the requirements needed from its nurses. In some cases, the standards for nurse licensing in New Jersey are higher than other participating jurisdictions. Could allowing nurses from other states who adhere to fewer restrictions diminish the quality of care provided to patients in the Garden State? This is a valid question which concerned parties have expressed.


## What are the Benefits of New Jersey Joining the eNLC?

The official New Jersey Business and Industry Association is in strong support of the bill as it will help make it easier to recruit the much-needed nursing staff. A nurse and clinical professor at Rutgers School of Nursing and also a lead for the New Jersey Collaborating Center for Nursing (which studies workforce issues), Edna Cadmus [stated](http://www.njccn.org/):

> “I see this as a very positive step. It allows for greater mobility, and greater mobility will help us in dealing with shortages. It also really helps reduce some of the duplication in licensing.”


## How Supply and Demand Affects Nurses Working in New Jersey and Nationwide

If a nurse who currently holds a license in New Jersey wants to work in another state, they must seek out licensure in that state. Vice versa, if a nurse wants to take a job position in New Jersey, they must obtain Garden State credentials. Either way, the New Jersey Board of Nursing already oversees the credentials of more than 220,000 healthcare professionals, of which, more than half are registered nurses or RNs. It’s this same board of nursing that is in charge of processing all this licensing and managing all the aspects of education and regulations in the profession.

Some people insist that the management concerns and staff shortages at the board have made it much more challenging to obtain nursing certification in New Jersey. Those who are critics of the multi-state compact in the state of New Jersey argue that by adding this increased workload to the nursing board, the problem with delays will only be exacerbated.

Several years ago, lawmakers and advocates [brought these issues of the board being overburdened to attention](https://www.njspotlight.com/stories/17/10/05/critics-say-chronic-problems-in-nj-nursing-board-are-danger-to-patients/) and the former Gov. Chris Christie appointed additional board members at that time. Regardless, the state officials at that time suggested that the board had appropriate staffing. The state nursing board falls under the Department of Consumer Affairs in New Jersey.


## Supply and Demand for Nurses Nationwide Varies

Substantial variability exists in the supply and demand of the workforce of nurses from state to state according to a report from the national Health Resources and Services Administration (which is a division of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services) from [July 2017.](http://www.njccn.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HRSA-Supply-and-Demand-2014-2030.pdf)

As an example of this supply and demand variables, it’s estimated that by 2030 New Jersey will be short by about 11,400 nurses (which will make it one of four states looking at 10,000-plus deficiency) – but at that same time, it’s estimated that New York will have at least 18,000 nurses in surplus.


## History of the Nurse Licensure Compact

The very first multi-state compact involved Texas and Wisconsin in 2000, and the [National Council of State Boards of Nursing](https://www.ncsbn.org/nurse-licensure-compact.htm) helped organize the arrangement. Since then, the agreement has gained steam and there are currently 29 states involved in the compact, with more that have agreed to join soon and several others with pending legislation.


## Nurses Unions have Concerns Regarding Multi-State Licensure

There are 11 states that have not gotten involved in the talks regarding joining the compact such as New York and Pennsylvania, and this also includes labor-friendly states such as Ohio and California. There are nurses unions, such as the Health Professionals and Allied Employees (which is the largest group of this kind in New Jersey), who have not shown support for the plan because they are concerned that this could [lower the standards](https://www.njspotlight.com/stories/15/10/22/rise-of-telemedicine-drives-move-toward-multi-state-nursing-agreement/) for workfoce qualifications. Earlier versions of the bill raised concerns like this with the New Jersey State Nurses Association, but the compact in its current form is fully supported by this body.

The criminal background check processes are at the core of these types of concerns. There are several states which are part of the compact that do not have the same level of requirements when it comes to checking the criminal background history of a nurse. The argument, therefore, is that this agreement could allow nurses with dangerous backgrounds to work in the Garden State.

In 2001, it was this very concern that was mostly responsible for the failure of the previous attempt made for New Jersey to join the eNLC. However, since 2006, there has been bi-partisan support to [re-start the process](https://www.njspotlight.com/stories/15/10/22/rise-of-telemedicine-drives-move-toward-multi-state-nursing-agreement/). Groups such as HPAE have been urging lawmakers to include requirements that would mandate any out-of-state nurse to meet the requirements according to the standards in New Jersey, but so far none of those efforts made it through the committees and floor votes.

If the governor were to sign the latest version of the law [(S-954)](https://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2018/Bills/S1000/954_R1.PDF), it would immediately go into effect. The [legislation is](https://www.njspotlight.com/stories/19/02/21/nj-moves-closer-to-joining-multi-state-licensing-pact-for-nurses/) “led by Sens. Joseph Vitale (D-Middlesex), the longtime health committee chairman, Troy Singleton (D-Burlington) and Fred Madden (D-Gloucester) and co-sponsored by Sen. Declan O’Scanlon (R-Monmouth). Assemblyman Herb Conaway (D-Burlington), a physician and chair of that house’s health committee, heads up the companion version, which cleared several Assembly panels last month.”

If it goes through, New Jersey will be able to participate in the compact and share nurses [both RNs and licensed practical/vocational nurses (LPN/VNs)] from the license pool. The state will also be required to participate in the interstate commission that operates the compact.

Under the proposed agreement, if a nurse working in the Garden State violates the regulations set forth by the state, New Jersey would be allowed to revoke or suspend the license of any nurse in the pool, regardless of where they live or where they are licensed. Any adverse actions such taken by the state would need to be logged in the shared database. There is also an operating fee of $6,000 annually that would need to be paid by the officials of the state for the expenses of the compact.

Furthermore, the agreement will require the New Jersey Attorney General to evaluate how the participation in the compact is doing after one year’s time and report the pros and cons to the governor and Legislature. If the evaluation made by the AG suggests that states with lower standards for licensing have joined the group (which could allow less-qualified caregivers to work in New Jersey) – the state would be allowed to withdraw from the compact at that time.

At Elite Specialty Staffing, we follow and report on the issues that matter most to travel nurses. Stay posted to our [blog](https://elitespecialtystaffing.com/blog/) as we cover these topics and more.

Assemblyman Herb Conaway (D-Burlington), a physician and chair of that house’s health committee, heads up the companion version, which cleared several Assembly panels last month.”

If it goes through, New Jersey will be able to participate in the compact and share nurses [both RNs and licensed practical/vocational nurses (LPN/VNs)] from the license pool. The state will also be required to participate in the interstate commission that operates the compact.

Under the proposed agreement, if a nurse working in the Garden State violates the regulations set forth by the state, New Jersey would be allowed to revoke or suspend the license of any nurse in the pool, regardless of where they live or where they are licensed. Any adverse actions such taken by the state would need to be logged in the shared database. There is also an operating fee of $6,000 annually that would need to be paid by the officials of the state for the expenses of the compact.

Furthermore, the agreement will require the New Jersey Attorney General to evaluate how the participation in the compact is doing after one year’s time and report the pros and cons to the governor and Legislature. If the evaluation made by the AG suggests that states with lower standards for licensing have joined the group (which could allow less-qualified caregivers to work in New Jersey) – the state would be allowed to withdraw from the compact at that time.

At Elite Specialty Staffing, we follow and report on the issues that matter most to travel nurses. Stay posted to our blog as we cover these topics and more.

posts.title: Nursing Informatics Jobs: the Rising Nursing Specialty
posts.markdown:
Nursing informatics is a division of nursing that’s rapidly growing and shows no signs of slowing down any time soon. Why? This field is expanding exponentially because of the importance of nursing informatics and the impact it has on everyday patient care, documentation, and procedures.

Analysis of current healthcare IT systems and the implementation of new software in healthcare, such as electronic health records (EHR), have profound implications for the delivery of healthcare and patient outcomes. As a nurse or even a travel nurse, working in healthcare IT, you are trusted to combine your clinical nursing skills and technical knowledge to help improve patient care.

As hospitals increase their usage and dependence on healthcare IT systems such as EHRs, electronic order entering systems, and coding applications, there is a growing demand for technical departments that have both clinical and non-clinical professionals working in them. As a nurse informaticist, you can become a core member of a hospital or health system’s clinical IT team.


## What is Nursing Informatics?

A field of nursing which focuses on the delivery of high-quality patient care through the analysis and management of healthcare data and technical systems is called nursing informatics. A nurse working in the informatics field can:

- Analyze trends
- Monitor for recurrent errors
- Implement new systems
- Improve the efficiency of current processes


## How do You Find Nursing Informatics Jobs?

Nursing informatics jobs come in many different settings and roles and can be found under various titles. The following are types of roles and titles given to nurses working in informatics, (their specifics may vary):

- Nurse informaticist
- Nursing informatics specialist
- Nursing informatics clinician
- Clinical informatics coordinator
- Clinical analyst
- Clinical nurse informatics specialist
- IT clinical nurse
- Perioperative informatics nurse


## Nursing Informatics Job Descriptions

*Healthcare* informatics is a field that deals mostly with the administrative side of healthcare data, such as registration and billing applications. *Nursing* informatics brings in the patient care aspect of healthcare and deals with the computer systems interacted with by the nursing and care staff. As such, registered nurses who work in informatics serve as a point of contact between the clinical nursing staff and the IT team or department.


## What’s the Importance of Nursing Informatics?

Nursing informaticists effectively bridge the gap in communication between the clinicians using the software every day and the technical folk working “in the trenches” on the backend of the development and rollout of such applications. Effectively, nurse informaticists can make sure that the new tools and procedures being implemented will be practical and user-friendly for the application and use of such systems by all staff members involved.

Because a nurse with a clinical and technical background can help see both sides of the spectrum, they are in a unique position to help demonstrate how systems can be used to provide the best care for patients. Let’s say a group of medical-surgical nurses is given training by a nursing informaticist, once that training is complete, that IT nurse will effectively serve as a point-of-contact for any questions that arise once the system is in place.

In addition to serving as a liaison between these two entities, nurse informaticists might also take part in:

- Quality control
- Systems development
- Clinical staff training


## Responsibilities of Nurses Working in Informatics

Hospitals are the most common employer for nursing informaticists according to a [study](https://www.himss.org/sites/himssorg/files/2017-nursing-informatics-workforce-full-report.pdf) conducted by the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS). System implementations were cited as the most frequent job responsibility for IT nurses at 40 percent according to the study. Within this blanket term of implementation includes the preparation of new technology and the support and training of clinical staff members.


## Where Do Nurse Informaticists Work?

Ever since the implementation of Meaningful Use and hospitals and healthcare facilities were driven to implement digital solutions, such as electronic health records (EHR) and computerized order entry (CPOE), technology solutions have been deeply entrenched throughout the healthcare realm. Therefore, nurses who work in informatics are needed in practically every clinical and healthcare setting that exists, including:

- Hospitals
- Consulting firms
- Universities
- Corporations
- Nursing homes
- Public heath firms
- Research laboratories
- Insurance agencies


## Nursing Informatics Job Outlook and Salary

The [Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/healthcare/registered-nurses.htm) estimates that the job market for nurses in general if going to rise by 15 percent by 2026. As people get older, but are leading healthier lives, there is an increased demand for many healthcare services which drives the nation’s need for nurses.

One of the biggest factors that increases the need for nurse informaticists is the push for controlling healthcare spending and costs. The proper management of nursing data in medical facilities and hospitals can help managers and executives implement policies and make decisions that effectively lower healthcare costs.

Because of this, the American Medical Informatics Association suggests that as many as [70,000 nursing informatics specialists/analysts](http://nursing.advanceweb.com/Features/Articles/Nursing-Informatics-A-Career-on-the-Rise.aspx) might be needed in the next five years. The Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act (HITECH) passed in 2009, and the Patient Protection and Accountable Care Act (PPACA) are two driving pieces of legislation that are responsible for the surge in the demand for nurses who work in informatics.

### Nursing Informatics Salary Details

- So how much do nurse informaticists make? According to [Indeed.com](http://www.indeed.com/salary?q1=nurse+informatics&l1=&tm=1) – the average nurse working in informatics makes $66,000 annually.
- If you take a look at the numbers on [Payscale.com](http://www.payscale.com/research/US/Job=Nursing_Informatics_Specialist/Salary) – they estimate that the average salary for nurses who work in IT varies from $49,000 to $87,000 annually.

Why is there so much variability in these figures you might ask? Usually the pay is going to vary based on experience. An entry-level IT nurse is going to earn towards the lower-end and highly-experienced professionals, who perhaps have an advanced degree, will earn towards the higher end of the scale.


## What are the Requirements to Work in Nursing Informatics

The majority of all nurse informaticists start their careers as registered nurses. You can apply for positions in the IT field in healthcare as an RN and gain experience from there. Nurses who work in informatics often have higher degrees of education. Many of them earn a BSN and even go on to earn their master’s of science in nursing or MSN. Nurse informaticists may also earn their master’s in computer science or information.

Are you up for the challenge? A career in the healthcare IT realm is demaning and requires extensive:

- Project management
- Critical thinking
- Creativity

You must be able to work in different environments and with a variety of people. Challenges arise during the development of information systems that meet everyone’s needs and you must be able to resolve those demands and come up with creative solutions to solve the conflicts.


## Searching for Travel Nursing Assignments?

Nurses trust Elite Specialty Staffing to provide the highest-paying travel nursing jobs in the industry. Available jobs with our agency are scattered across the nation, and we often have travel IT positions that need to be filled. To find out more, give us a call today at [208-378-1338](tel:208-378-1338).

posts.title: Taking a Pet on a Travel Nursing Contract? Here are 10 Tips
posts.markdown: Companionship. Cuddles. Protection. Pets bring so much joy and satisfaction to the lives of their owners. If you are a pet owner and happen to be a travel nurse, a pet can also provide a sense of home while you’re away from home. As such, many travel nurses choose to bring their pet along with them during an assignment. However, there are a lot of factors that can cause increased stress and anxiety for your pet during traveling such as long rides and plane trips. Furthermore, to bring your pet along to a travel nursing assignment can also add complexities to your logistics and travel arrangements. For these reasons, we have compiled these 10 travel nursing tips for bringing pets with you while you’re on assignment. ## 10 Travel Nursing Tips for Bringing Pets on Assignment ### 1. Plan Ahead to Travel with a Pet Travel nursing is all about planning ahead. In our previous blog post, we talked about how to [prepare for your first travel nursing assignment](https://elitespecialtystaffing.com/wordpress/11-tips-to-prepare-for-your-first-travel-nursing-job/). A huge part of that planning included being sure all of your licensing, credentials, and documents are up to date. Same goes for your pet. Even if your pet is in perfect health, be sure to take them into a vet before you travel. At this appointment, get copies of your pet’s vaccination records and associated health records. You will also want to plan ahead and research the area you are traveling to for local veterinarians. It’s a good idea to find a vet in the area you will be working on a travel nursing assignment that is open 24 hours in case you run into an emergency with your pet while you’re there. ### 2. Be Sure Your Pet Has Identification Does your dog or cat have an updated ID tag with your correct information on it? Be sure they do! If you haven’t already, get an ID tag for your dog that has your phone number and contact information visible and easy to read. You never know what could happen. While I was working on a travel nursing assignment, I had my dachshund escape from the camper when I looked away for just a moment! Luckily, she was wearing her ID tag with my current phone number on it, and she was found by a couple who called me and had her in their truck waiting to be picked up! If you haven’t already had your pet microchipped, this would be the time to do it. No one likes to think about the worst case scenario, but there is an increased chance that your pet might get lost or out of your sight in an unfamiliar environment. If your pet has been microchipped, it will be much more likely you’ll be able to find them and reunite if they were to get lost. ### 3. Secure Housing and Accommodations that are Pet-Friendly While this travel nursing advice may seem obvious, it’s easy to get so wrapped up in the logistics of your next travel nursing assignment that you may overlook this important step! From early on, be sure that you communicate with your travel nursing recruiter that you will be bringing a pet along. This allows plenty of time for your travel nursing staffing agency to secure pet-friendly housing. If you plan on driving to your assignment, consider where you might stay if you have any necessary stops along the way. As you are mapping out the trip, figure out which hotels are pet-friendly along your route. ### 4. Take Time for Breaks During the Trip Most fur babies travel with their owners by car to a [travel nursing assignment](https://elitespecialtystaffing.com/wordpress/jobs/). If you are driving for several hours to get to your destination with your pet, be sure that you bring a carrier to keep them secure and allow for breaks. Dogs and cats alike will need to be taken out of their carrier as needed to stretch their legs or use the bathroom. Don’t get so caught up in the drive that you forget about your pet. ### 5. Pack Accordingly for Your Pet Certainly, you have a few comfort items that you want to be sure you bring with you for your assignment. Your pet is no different. Does your dog have a favorite toy? Does your cat have a certain bed they like to sleep on? By bringing along creature comforts that your pet is used to, it will help them to feel at home and comfortable during the travel nursing assignment. My long-haired dachshund, Zoey, loved nothing more than putting on a cute little outfit and prancing around (seriously, this dog loved her clothes). For my travel nursing assignments in Florida, I brought along a couple of her favorite duds, and of course, her doggy bikini she proudly wore on the dog beaches. We also packed her items she used daily such as her bed and food bowels. ### 6. Bring a Travel Kit and Cleaning Supplies for the Trip Traveling can be very stressful on pets. Even if your dog or cat never has accidents at home, you never know what can happen when you’re on the road. The last thing you want is to have your precious pet make an accident while en route, and you be helpless to clean it up. Bring a travel kit for your pet that includes all of their paperwork, medication, food, and cleaning supplies. ### 7. Arrive to Your Assignment a Couple Days Early If you want to ensure your travel nursing assignment with your pet is a successful one, you should arrive at the location at least a couple of days in advance. This allows your pet to get acclimated to their new environment. If you’re bringing a dog with you, be sure you take it for a walk around the neighborhood so it will be less fearful and more aware of the new location they are living in. ### 8. Consider Using a Pet Daycare Nurses work long hours – usually 12-hour shifts. If you are traveling alone, this means that your pet is going to be spending significant time in solitude. If you are able to, you should really consider a doggy day care where your pet can go while you’re at work. Some facilities also accept cats. You should be able to find such a service before you arrive for your assignment simply by searching online. By using a pet daycare service, you will be able to work feeling more relaxed knowing that your pet is receiving proper care while you’re gone. ### 9. Set a Routine One of the very best ways to reduce fear and anxiety in your pet (and also helps to avoid accidents) is to set a routine and stick to it. Feed your pet the same time each day. Take them for a walk the same time each day. When your pet knows when they are supposed to use the bathroom each day, they will be less likely to have an accident. This practice also helps create a sense of familiarity and “home” for your pet, making them more comfortable during your travel nursing assignment. ### 10. Do Not Neglect Your Pet When you arrive home after a long work day, the first thing you might want to do (especially if you work nights) is crawl into bed and get some zzzs. Before you do, make a conscious effort to first spend some time with your pet who was without you all day long. Take them for a short walk. Pull out their favorite toy and play. Or, just grab them up and get in some cuddle time. Afterall, pets are very therapuetic and this time together will also make you feel good and help you decompress from travel nursing. ## Are You Ready to Plan a Travel Nursing Assignment? Our specialty nursing staffing agency is here to help you. Our experience in the industry can help you make the appropriate plans for your assignment, which includes finding pet-friendly housing when needed. Call us today at [208-378-1338](tel:208-378-1338) to hear about our available opportunities.

Companionship. Cuddles. Protection. Pets bring so much joy and satisfaction to the lives of their owners. If you are a pet owner and happen to be a travel nurse, a pet can also provide a sense of home while you’re away from home. As such, many travel nurses choose to bring their pet along with them during an assignment.

However, there are a lot of factors that can cause increased stress and anxiety for your pet during traveling such as long rides and plane trips. Furthermore, to bring your pet along to a travel nursing assignment can also add complexities to your logistics and travel arrangements. For these reasons, we have compiled these 10 travel nursing tips for bringing pets with you while you’re on assignment.

10 Travel Nursing Tips for Bringing Pets on Assignment

1. Plan Ahead to Travel with a Pet

Travel nursing is all about planning ahead. In our previous blog post, we talked about how to prepare for your first travel nursing assignment. A huge part of that planning included being sure all of your licensing, credentials, and documents are up to date. Same goes for your pet.

Even if your pet is in perfect health, be sure to take them into a vet before you travel. At this appointment, get copies of your pet’s vaccination records and associated health records.

You will also want to plan ahead and research the area you are traveling to for local veterinarians. It’s a good idea to find a vet in the area you will be working on a travel nursing assignment that is open 24 hours in case you run into an emergency with your pet while you’re there.

2. Be Sure Your Pet Has Identification

Does your dog or cat have an updated ID tag with your correct information on it? Be sure they do! If you haven’t already, get an ID tag for your dog that has your phone number and contact information visible and easy to read. You never know what could happen.

While I was working on a travel nursing assignment, I had my dachshund escape from the camper when I looked away for just a moment! Luckily, she was wearing her ID tag with my current phone number on it, and she was found by a couple who called me and had her in their truck waiting to be picked up!

If you haven’t already had your pet microchipped, this would be the time to do it. No one likes to think about the worst case scenario, but there is an increased chance that your pet might get lost or out of your sight in an unfamiliar environment. If your pet has been microchipped, it will be much more likely you’ll be able to find them and reunite if they were to get lost.

3. Secure Housing and Accommodations that are Pet-Friendly

While this travel nursing advice may seem obvious, it’s easy to get so wrapped up in the logistics of your next travel nursing assignment that you may overlook this important step!

From early on, be sure that you communicate with your travel nursing recruiter that you will be bringing a pet along. This allows plenty of time for your travel nursing staffing agency to secure pet-friendly housing.

If you plan on driving to your assignment, consider where you might stay if you have any necessary stops along the way. As you are mapping out the trip, figure out which hotels are pet-friendly along your route.

4. Take Time for Breaks During the Trip

Most fur babies travel with their owners by car to a travel nursing assignment. If you are driving for several hours to get to your destination with your pet, be sure that you bring a carrier to keep them secure and allow for breaks. Dogs and cats alike will need to be taken out of their carrier as needed to stretch their legs or use the bathroom. Don’t get so caught up in the drive that you forget about your pet.

5. Pack Accordingly for Your Pet

Certainly, you have a few comfort items that you want to be sure you bring with you for your assignment. Your pet is no different. Does your dog have a favorite toy? Does your cat have a certain bed they like to sleep on? By bringing along creature comforts that your pet is used to, it will help them to feel at home and comfortable during the travel nursing assignment. My long-haired dachshund, Zoey, loved nothing more than putting on a cute little outfit and prancing around (seriously, this dog loved her clothes). For my travel nursing assignments in Florida, I brought along a couple of her favorite duds, and of course, her doggy bikini she proudly wore on the dog beaches. We also packed her items she used daily such as her bed and food bowels.

6. Bring a Travel Kit and Cleaning Supplies for the Trip

Traveling can be very stressful on pets. Even if your dog or cat never has accidents at home, you never know what can happen when you’re on the road. The last thing you want is to have your precious pet make an accident while en route, and you be helpless to clean it up. Bring a travel kit for your pet that includes all of their paperwork, medication, food, and cleaning supplies.

7. Arrive to Your Assignment a Couple Days Early

If you want to ensure your travel nursing assignment with your pet is a successful one, you should arrive at the location at least a couple of days in advance. This allows your pet to get acclimated to their new environment. If you’re bringing a dog with you, be sure you take it for a walk around the neighborhood so it will be less fearful and more aware of the new location they are living in.

8. Consider Using a Pet Daycare

Nurses work long hours – usually 12-hour shifts. If you are traveling alone, this means that your pet is going to be spending significant time in solitude. If you are able to, you should really consider a doggy day care where your pet can go while you’re at work. Some facilities also accept cats. You should be able to find such a service before you arrive for your assignment simply by searching online. By using a pet daycare service, you will be able to work feeling more relaxed knowing that your pet is receiving proper care while you’re gone.

9. Set a Routine

One of the very best ways to reduce fear and anxiety in your pet (and also helps to avoid accidents) is to set a routine and stick to it. Feed your pet the same time each day. Take them for a walk the same time each day. When your pet knows when they are supposed to use the bathroom each day, they will be less likely to have an accident. This practice also helps create a sense of familiarity and “home” for your pet, making them more comfortable during your travel nursing assignment.

10. Do Not Neglect Your Pet

When you arrive home after a long work day, the first thing you might want to do (especially if you work nights) is crawl into bed and get some zzzs. Before you do, make a conscious effort to first spend some time with your pet who was without you all day long. Take them for a short walk. Pull out their favorite toy and play. Or, just grab them up and get in some cuddle time. Afterall, pets are very therapuetic and this time together will also make you feel good and help you decompress from travel nursing.

Are You Ready to Plan a Travel Nursing Assignment?

Our specialty nursing staffing agency is here to help you. Our experience in the industry can help you make the appropriate plans for your assignment, which includes finding pet-friendly housing when needed. Call us today at 208-378-1338 to hear about our available opportunities.

posts.title: Travel Nursing Tips: 5 Ways to Decompress During Time Off
posts.markdown:
Relocation. Changing nursing jobs. Long shifts. Saving lives. Travel nurses work hard!

Dealing with all the extra pressures of adapting to new environments while leveraging a family life and social life can be taxing on your energy and motivation. Stress may be inevitable to a degree, but in order to stay healthy and prevent the stress from affecting you mentally, physically, or spiritually – decompression and downtime are key!

Stress can mess you up. It can affect your sleep. Mood. Anxiety levels. It’s important to do something, anything, to help you de-stress and decompress during your time off travel nursing assignments or even after a long shift.

There’s no denying that travel nurses work hard. And, with the added pressure of adapting to new environments, family, and social life on top of taking care of all your patients, it’s natural to get a little stressed every now and then. But, in order to be your very best, it’s important to not let the stress take control of your mind and body.

Here are five travel nursing tips on how to decompress and make the most of your time off.


## 1. Don’t Take Your Work Home with You

When I was working as a travel nurse, I often had to remind myself not to take my work home with me. For some people that work in the service industry or a factory setting, this type of conscious effort might be easier than it is for a nurse – you clock out and you’re done.

While working as a travel nurse, it may not seem so cut and dry. The stress of learning a whole new routine in an unfamiliar work environment can be challenging. Not to mention, working as a registered nurse and being there for patients during their most critical times and working closely with their family members concerning serious issues can be heavy day to day. But when you clock out, try free your mind of the workplace and avoid the habit of talking about work while you’re not there.

One way to help accomplish this is to make use of a provided locker space on-site and physically drop off your things while mentally reminding yourself work stays at work. Bring a combination lock, and leave things at your workplace you either don’t need while you’re not working or don’t want to have to laying around reminding you of work, plus you don’t have to worry about forgetting items, like your name badge!

For me, I left everything except my scrubs at the facility. My badge, clipboard, hemostats, random collection of 2x2s, tape, scissors, flashlight – you know all the typical arsenal a nurse uses – along with my nursing shoes. Keeping your nursing shoes clean and out of the weather and out of your living space with random hospital germs, is a great time saver and a way to leave work at work!


## 2. Take Time to Exercise

Get the endorphins flowing. Even if it’s just a little bit. Exercise is the worst enemy of stress. It simply can’t survive in its presence. Making the effort to get your body moving is going to pay off with gains in both the short term and the long term.

While getting off work following a butt-kicking 12-hour shift might not have you feeling inspired to get to the gym – you might be surprised how effective working out right after work can be. It’s a great way to clear your mind and unwind after a day working as a travel nurse.

Do what makes sense for your schedule. If you feel like going for a run, do it. Hitting the gym? More power to you. At the very least, you can also walk around the facility you work. Even if you do not have the time to get the exercise in post-shift, you can increase your movement by taking the steps and challenging yourself to walk as much as possible while at work. No matter how fast you’re going, [exercise is going to send energy throughout your body and increase endorphins and blood flow to the brain](https://adaa.org/living-with-anxiety/managing-anxiety/exercise-stress-and-anxiety).


## 3. Pay Extra Attention to Self-Care

A common theme among travel nurses I worked with in the IT implementation field is that many of them were obsessed with self-care in the form of manicures, pedicures, massages, and I am sure you can include hair treatments, etc. To be honest, the job was amazing in the aspect that it was not tiring physically and you were basically were expected to stay awake and be available to answer questions when needed. Once the hospital staff was on the system for about a week, the rest of the three-month assignment had several shifts in which I answered only five or less questions in an entire 12-hour work day.

At first, I did not understand how many of the experienced traveling IT nurses would feel so stressed and splurge on self-pampering. However, this particular assignment offered (and most people took up) 12-hour shifts five to seven days a week. After I worked several 60-hour work weeks, I finally understood that even though the work was not physically exhausting and stressful, like staff nursing is, being at work for those long hours takes its toll. Taking the time to care for yourself helps keep you refreshed, it lifts your spirits, and can potentially help you avoid nursing burnout.


## 4. Clear Your Thoughts Through Meditation or Prayer

Even if you’re not into yoga per say – there is still great value in the practice of meditation. Do not be confused and think that you need incense and yoga pants in order to meditate. According to the [Mirriam-Webster dictionary](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/meditate), meditation means:

1. “To engage in contemplation or reflection; or
2. To engage in mental exercise (such as concentration on one’s breathing or repetition of a mantra) for the purpose of reaching a heightened level of spiritual awareness.”

Prayer is another way you can spend time clearing your thoughts and feeding your spirituality. By taking this time to yourself where everything else is quiet and you can focus on your inner peace and thought processes, you can regroup, refocus, and recharge your spiritual energy – which you can use to provide the best possible care to patients without getting burned out.


## 5. Don’t Forget to be a Tourist on Days Off

One of the top reasons why nurses choose to [become a travel nurse](https://elitespecialtystaffing.com/trade-in-your-permanent-address-to-become-a-travel-nurse/) is to explore new locations and experience new cultures and meet new people. All too often, we as travel nurses get so caught up in doing the best we can to do a great job while we are at work, that we spend our time off simply trying to rest and prepare to go back to work.

Instead of thinking about work on your days off, remember why you became a travel nurse in the first place, which includes experiencing new things. Grab your camera and your best “tacky” tourist shirt you can find (ok you can leave the shirt at home if you’re not into that kind of thing), and get out there and explore the city you’re working in. Find tourist websites and create a list of attractions and venues you want to see while you’re on assignment.

On your days off, make a special effort to get out there and see and do all the things on your list. Also, keep your mind open to new opportunities as they arise that weren’t on your initial list. “Where does this hiking trail lead?” You’ll never know unless you walk it. Who knows, you might just stumble upon the most beautiful waterfall you’ve seen. Follow your intuition and be spontaneous, while using your smarts to stay safe.


## Ready to Find Your Dream Travel Nursing Job?

Call us today at [208-378-1338](tel: 208-378-1338) to learn more about our opportunities for you to land the highest-paying travel nursing jobs in the United States.
posts.html:
Relocation. Changing nursing jobs. Long shifts. Saving lives. Travel nurses work hard!

Dealing with all the extra pressures of adapting to new environments while leveraging a family life and social life can be taxing on your energy and motivation. Stress may be inevitable to a degree, but in order to stay healthy and prevent the stress from affecting you mentally, physically, or spiritually – decompression and downtime are key!

Stress can mess you up. It can affect your sleep. Mood. Anxiety levels. It’s important to do something, anything, to help you de-stress and decompress during your time off travel nursing assignments or even after a long shift.

There’s no denying that travel nurses work hard. And, with the added pressure of adapting to new environments, family, and social life on top of taking care of all your patients, it’s natural to get a little stressed every now and then. But, in order to be your very best, it’s important to not let the stress take control of your mind and body.

Here are five travel nursing tips on how to decompress and make the most of your time off.

1. Don’t Take Your Work Home with You

When I was working as a travel nurse, I often had to remind myself not to take my work home with me. For some people that work in the service industry or a factory setting, this type of conscious effort might be easier than it is for a nurse – you clock out and you’re done.

While working as a travel nurse, it may not seem so cut and dry. The stress of learning a whole new routine in an unfamiliar work environment can be challenging. Not to mention, working as a registered nurse and being there for patients during their most critical times and working closely with their family members concerning serious issues can be heavy day to day. But when you clock out, try free your mind of the workplace and avoid the habit of talking about work while you’re not there.

One way to help accomplish this is to make use of a provided locker space on-site and physically drop off your things while mentally reminding yourself work stays at work. Bring a combination lock, and leave things at your workplace you either don’t need while you’re not working or don’t want to have to laying around reminding you of work, plus you don’t have to worry about forgetting items, like your name badge!

For me, I left everything except my scrubs at the facility. My badge, clipboard, hemostats, random collection of 2x2s, tape, scissors, flashlight – you know all the typical arsenal a nurse uses – along with my nursing shoes. Keeping your nursing shoes clean and out of the weather and out of your living space with random hospital germs, is a great time saver and a way to leave work at work!

2. Take Time to Exercise

Get the endorphins flowing. Even if it’s just a little bit. Exercise is the worst enemy of stress. It simply can’t survive in its presence. Making the effort to get your body moving is going to pay off with gains in both the short term and the long term.

  1. “To engage in contemplation or reflection; or
  2. To engage in mental exercise (such as concentration on one’s breathing or repetition of a mantra) for the purpose of reaching a heightened level of spiritual awareness.”

animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”]

You Deserve the Highest Paying Travel Nursing Jobs

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Subtitle” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” text_font_size=”20px” header_font=”||||||||” background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”] Your job is more than a career. Working as a travel nurse is a calling. It’s not for the weak and it’s not for the faint of heart. At Elite Speciality Staffing, we admire your dedication to the nursing profession. We understand your passion and commitment and we will support you to advance your nursing career. As one of the top travel nursing companies in the United States with more than 15 years of experience in the travel nursing industry, Elite Specialty Staffing offers registered nurses exactly what they want: [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.17.1″ module_alignment=”center”][et_pb_column type=”1_3″][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Subtitle” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” text_font_size=”20px” header_font=”||||||||” background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”]
  • Exclusive contracts
  • The highest pay rates
  • The most competitive travel nursing benefits packages
[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row custom_width_px=”710px” custom_padding=”30px|0px|30px|0px|true|false” background_position_1=”top_left” background_repeat_1=”no-repeat” _builder_version=”3.0.65″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Title” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” header_font=”Montserrat||||” header_text_color=”#1f1f1f” header_font_size=”36px” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”]

Travel Nursing Jobs on Your Terms

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Subtitle” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” text_font_size=”20px” header_font=”||||||||” background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”] Want to work three 12-hour shifts per week? You got it! What did you say? You’d rather have four 12-hour shifts per week? We can do that too. Maybe you want to work days, five days per week on 8-hour shifts? No problem. The best registered nurses in the industry trust us at Elite to help place them on the travel nursing assignments they want that fit their needs and their schedule. If you are looking for nursing assignments only by the shift, learn more about our highest paying per diem nursing jobs here. Flexibility. Options. Feel confident going into your next travel nursing assignment with Elite that your preferences have been carefully matched to the ideal contract for you! Work your way, everyday. Our staffing specialists take their time to consider all of your needs before sending you off to work on a travel nursing contract. [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row custom_width_px=”710px” custom_padding=”30px|0px|30px|0px|true|false” background_position_1=”top_left” background_repeat_1=”no-repeat” _builder_version=”3.0.65″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Title” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” header_font=”Montserrat||||” header_text_color=”#1f1f1f” header_font_size=”36px” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”]

Earn more money. Love your work. Live better.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Subtitle” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” text_font_size=”20px” header_font=”||||||||” background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”] What is a travel nurse? There’s more to nurses than the scrubs they wear and the medications they pass. A travel nurse is one who extends their services to the hospitals, healthcare clinics, and doctors’ offices from around the country that need their skills the most. Every single day that you work as a travel nurse, you’re making a difference. You’re helping the most vulnerable people in society; patients. [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row custom_width_px=”710px” custom_padding=”30px|0px|30px|0px|true|false” background_position_1=”top_left” background_repeat_1=”no-repeat” _builder_version=”3.0.65″ background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Title” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” header_font=”Montserrat||||” header_text_color=”#1f1f1f” header_font_size=”36px” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”]

What are the Benefits of Travel Nursing?

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text admin_label=”Services Section Subtitle” _builder_version=”3.17.1″ text_font=”||||||||” text_font_size=”20px” header_font=”||||||||” background_size=”initial” background_position=”top_left” background_repeat=”repeat” text_orientation=”center” max_width=”710px” module_alignment=”center” animation_style=”fold” animation_direction=”bottom” animation_intensity_fold=”20%”] It’s no secret that the enticing benefits of travel nursing are some of the main reasons so many registered nurses choose to travel. When you accept a travel nursing contract with Elite, the following are some of the benefits you will enjoy: [/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row custom_padding=”30px|0px|30px|0px|true|false” _builder_version=”3.17.1″][et_pb_column type=”1_3″][/et_pb_column][et_pb_column type=”1_3″][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.17.1″]
  • Competitive travel nursing wages
  • Flexible scheduling options
  • Full-time hourly bonuses
  • Direct deposit pay
  • Travel reimbursement
  • Referral bonuses
  • Professional liability insurance
  • Worker’s compensation insurance
    • (NOTE: ALL OF THESE BULLETS CAN LINK OUT TO BENEFITS PAGES, and BENEFITS LANDING PAGE)

Why the Best Registered Nurses Choose Our Travel Nursing Agency

Without your hard work and professional skills, we could not deliver the medical staffing solutions that are at the core of our travel nursing agency. Whether you are looking for travel nursing jobs in Hawaii, travel nursing jobs in California, or any other state throughout the nation, start by checking out our current available travel nursing assignments on our jobs board.
